text: Again, what is to go in French?
Aller.
How would you say I want to go?
Je veux aller.
How about I want to go there?
Je veux y aller.
You can of course say aller là, but it's much less commonly used in French
and typically you can only really use it when you're gesturing towards somewhere very specific
and saying I want to go there to là.
So instead of saying aller là, you're much more likely to say y aller.
Y aller.
How would you say he wants to go there?
Il veut y aller.
He has in French.
What is he has?
Il a.
She has.
Elle a.
And again he has.
Il a.
Now this will sound strange to an English speaker,
but how would you say he has there using e for there?
Il y a.
Now this unusual expression in French, pronounced quickly, which it comes out as il y a,
means there is or there are.
If you translate it literally, it's something like it or he, there has.
Something like that.
So I suppose it's like saying that place over there has something.
So it is a bit like there is or there are because it's saying that the place has something.
So again, there is or there are is...
Il y a.
How would you say there's a cathedral here?
Il y a une cathédrale ici.
Adding is it that onto the beginning, how would you say is there a cathedral here?
Est-ce qu'il y a une cathédrale ici?
Now you'll notice that a French native speaker, they, when putting es-que and il-ia together,
well, the que on the end of es-que ends in a vowel.
And il-ia begins with a vowel, so there is an abbreviation.
If every single word is said without an abbreviation, what you would hear is...
Est-ce que il y a une cathédrale ici?
But what you will actually hear from French speakers is you will always hear it with the abbreviation.
So, que il becomes qu'il.
And the whole sentence, is there a cathedral here, comes out as...
Est-ce qu'il y a une cathédrale ici?
Again, it's something to get used to, but it's not impossible.
A market in French, a market is...
Un marché.
Un marché.
How would you say, is there a market here?
Est-ce qu'il y a un marché ici?
you
Thank you.
